content.content:
name: Language Change Proposals
description: Changes to the language
labels: ["Proposal", "LanguageChange", "LanguageChangeReview"]
title: "proposal: spec: proposal title"


body:
  - type: markdown
    attributes:
      value: |
       ## Our process for evaluating language changes can be found [here](https://go.googlesource.com/proposal/+/refs/heads/master#language-changes)

  - type: dropdown
    id: author-go-experience
    attributes:
      label: "Go Programming Experience"
      description: "Would you consider yourself a novice, intermediate, or experienced Go programmer?"
      options:
        - "Novice"
        - "Intermediate"
        - "Experienced"
      default: 1

  - type: input
    id: author-other-languages-experience
    attributes:
      label: "Other Languages Experience"
      description: "What other languages do you have experience with?"
      placeholder: "Go, Python, JS, Rust"
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: checkboxes
    id: related-idea
    attributes:
      label: "Related Idea"
      options:
        - label: "Has this idea, or one like it, been proposed before?"
        - label: "Does this affect error handling?"
        - label: "Is this about generics?"
        - label: "Is this change backward compatible? Breaking the Go 1 compatibility guarantee is a large cost and requires a large benefit"

  - type: textarea
    id: related-proposals
    attributes:
      label: Has this idea, or one like it, been proposed before?
      description: If so, how does this proposal differ?
      placeholder: |
       Yes or No

       If yes, 
        1. Mention the related proposals 
        2. then describe how this proposal differs       
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: error-handling-proposal
    attributes:
      label: Does this affect error handling?
      description: If so, how does this differ from previous error handling proposals?
      placeholder: |
       Yes or No

       If yes, 
        1.how does this differ from previous error handling proposals?

    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: generics-proposal
    attributes:
      label: Is this about generics?
      description: If so, how does this relate to the accepted design and other generics proposals?
      placeholder: |
       Yes or No

       If yes, 
        1. how does this relate to the accepted design and other generics proposals?

    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: proposal
    attributes:
      label: "Proposal"
      description: "What is the proposed change? Who does this proposal help, and why? Please describe as precisely as possible the change to the language."
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: language-spec-changes
    attributes:
      label: "Language Spec Changes"
      description: "What would change in the language spec?"
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: informal-change
    attributes:
      label: "Informal Change"
      description: "Please also describe the change informally, as in a class teaching Go."
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: go-backwards-compatiblity
    attributes:
      label: Is this change backward compatible?
      description: Breaking the Go 1 compatibility guarantee is a large cost and requires a large benefit.
      placeholder: |
       Yes or No

       If yes, 
        1. Show example code before and after the change.

    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: orthogonality
    attributes:
      label: "Orthogonality: How does this change interact or overlap with existing features?"
      description: "Is the goal of this change a performance improvement? If so, what quantifiable improvement should we expect? How would we measure it?"
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: learning-curve
    attributes:
      label: "Would this change make Go easier or harder to learn, and why?"

  - type: textarea
    id: cost-description
    attributes:
      label: "Cost Description"
      description: "What is the cost of this proposal? (Every language change has a cost)"

    id: go-toolchain

    validations:
      required: false

  - type: input
    id: perf-costs
    attributes:
      label: Performance Costs
      description: "What is the compile time cost? What is the run time cost? "
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: prototype
    attributes:
      label: "Prototype"
      description: "Can you describe a possible implementation?"
    validations:
      required: false

content.content:
name: Bug Report
description: File a bug report
labels: [bug]
body:
  - type: markdown
    attributes:
      value: |
        Thanks for taking the time to fill out this bug report! Please fill the form below.
  - type: textarea
    id: what-happened
    attributes:
      label: What happened?
      description: Also tell us, what did you expect to happen?
    validations:
      required: true
  - type: textarea
    id: reproducible
    attributes:
      label: How can we reproduce this?
      description: |
        Please share a code snippet, gist, or public repository that reproduces the issue.
        Make sure to make the reproducible as concise as possible,
        with only the minimum required code to reproduce the issue.
    validations:
      required: true
  - type: textarea
    id: version
    attributes:
      label: Which version of bubbletea are you using?
      description: ''
      render: bash
    validations:
      required: true
  - type: textarea
    id: terminaal
    attributes:
      label: Which terminals did you reproduce this with?
      description: |
        Other helpful information:
        was it over SSH?
        On tmux?
        Which version of said terminal?
    validations:
      required: true
  - type: checkboxes
    id: search
    attributes:
      label: Search
      options:
        - label: |
           I searched for other open and closed issues and pull requests before opening this,
           and didn't find anything that seems related.
          required: true
  - type: textarea
    id: ctx
    attributes:
      label: Additional context
      description: Anything else you would like to add
    validations:
      required: false

content.content:
---
name: v3 feature request
about: Suggest an improvement to go into v3
title: 'your feature title goes here'
labels: 'type/feature, area/v3, status/triage'
assignees: ''

---

## Checklist

* [ ] Are you running the latest v3 release? The list of releases is [here](https://github.com/urfave/cli/releases).
* [ ] Did you check the manual for your release? The v3 manual is [here](https://github.com/urfave/cli/blob/main/docs/v3/index.md).
* [ ] Did you perform a search about this feature? Here's the [GitHub guide](https://help.github.com/en/github/managing-your-work-on-github/using-search-to-filter-issues-and-pull-requests) about searching.

## What problem does this solve?

A clear and concise description of what problem this feature would solve. For example:

- needing to type out the full flag name takes a long time, so I
  would like to suggest adding auto-complete
- I use (osx, windows, linux) and would like support for (some
  existing feature) to be extended to my platform
- the terminal output for a particular error case is confusing, and
  I think it could be improved

## Solution description

A detailed description of what you want to happen.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or
features you've considered.

content.text:
---

# Feature Request Issue Templates: Research from Major Open Source Projects

## Raw Template Content

### 1. GitHub CLI (`cli/cli`) -- Markdown

**File:** `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/submit-a-request.md`

```markdown
---
name: "Submit a request"
about: Surface a feature or problem that you think should be solved
title: ''
labels: enhancement
assignees: ''
---

### Describe the feature or problem you'd like to solve

A clear and concise description of what the feature or problem is.

### Proposed solution

How will it benefit CLI and its users?

### Additional context

Add any other context like screenshots or mockups are helpful, if applicable.
```

**Notable:** They also have a separate `feedback.md` template with a friendly, informal tone ("What have you loved?", "What was confusing or gave you pause?"). They allow blank issues via `config.yml` and redirect questions to GitHub Discussions.

---

### 2. Go (`golang/go`) -- YAML Forms

**File:** `.REDACTED.yml`

```yaml
name: Proposals
description: New external API or other notable changes
title: "proposal: import/path: proposal title"
labels: ["Proposal"]
body:
  - type: markdown
    attributes:
      value: "Our process is documented here: https://go.dev/s/proposal-process"
  - type: textarea
    id: proposal-details
    attributes:
      label: "Proposal Details"
      description: "Please provide the details of your proposal here."
    validations:
      required: true
```

**Also notable -- their Language Change Proposal** (`11-language-change.yml`) is one of the most sophisticated templates in the wild. It uses:

- **Dropdowns** for experience level ("Novice", "Intermediate", "Experienced")
- **Checkboxes** for categorizing the change ("Has this been proposed before?", "Does this affect error handling?", "Is this about generics?", "Is this backward compatible?")
- **Input fields** (short text) for toolchain impact and performance costs
- **Multiple required textareas** covering: related proposals, error handling impact, generics impact, proposal details, backward compatibility, orthogonality, learning curve, cost description, and prototype

---

### 3. Kubernetes (`kubernetes/kubernetes`) -- YAML Forms

**File:** `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/enhancement.yaml`

```yaml
name: Enhancement Tracking Issue
description: Provide supporting details for a feature in development
labels: kind/feature
body:
  - type: textarea
    id: feature
    attributes:
      label: What would you like to be added?
      description: |
        Feature requests are unlikely to make progress as issues.
        Please consider engaging with SIGs on slack and mailing lists.
        A proposal that works through the design can be opened as a KEP.
        See https://git.k8s.io/enhancements/keps
    validations:
      required: true
  - type: textarea
    id: rationale
    attributes:
      label: Why is this needed?
    validations:
      required: true
```

**Notable:** Extremely minimal -- only two required fields. The description actively redirects users to the more formal KEP (Kubernetes Enhancement Proposal) process for serious features. The `config.yml` redirects support questions to discuss.kubernetes.io.

---

### 4. Docker CLI (`docker/cli`) -- YAML Forms

**File:** `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.yml`

```yaml
name: Feature request
description: Missing functionality? Come tell us about it!
labels:
  - kind/feature
  - status/0-triage
body:
  - type: textarea
    id: description
    attributes:
      label: Description
      description: What is the feature you want to see?
    validations:
      required: true
```

**Notable:** The simplest template of all -- a single required textarea. Uses a `status/0-triage` label for workflow automation. Welcoming description ("Missing functionality? Come tell us about it!").

---

### 5. Terraform (`hashicorp/terraform`) -- YAML Forms

**File:** `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.yml`

```yaml
name: Feature Request
description: Suggest a new feature or other enhancement.
labels: ["enhancement", "new"]
body:
  - type: markdown
    attributes:
      value: |
        # Thank you for opening a feature request.
        The issue tracker is reserved for feature requests relating
        to the core Terraform CLI application and configuration language.
        For general usage questions, see the Community Forum.

        ## If your feature request relates to:
        * **HCP Terraform or Terraform Enterprise**: email support
        * **AWS Terraform Provider**: Open issue at terraform-provider-aws
        * **Azure Terraform Provider**: Open issue at terraform-provider-azurerm
        * **Other Terraform Providers**: Open in provider's own repository

  - type: textarea
    id: tf-version
    attributes:
      label: Terraform Version
      description: Run `terraform version` to show the version
      render: shell
      placeholder: ...output of `terraform version`...
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: tf-use-case
    attributes:
      label: Use Cases
      description: |
        Describe the end goal you are trying to achieve.
        Keep this section focused on the problem, not the solution.
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: tf-attempted-solution
    attributes:
      label: Attempted Solutions
      description: |
        If you've tried to solve the problem within existing features,
        describe what you tried. Include config snippets and command lines.
        Remove any sensitive information.
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: tf-proposal
    attributes:
      label: Proposal
      description: |
        Describe how you'd address the problem via a change to features.
        Include specific examples of config files or command line usage.
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: tf-references
    attributes:
      label: References
      description: |
        Related GitHub issues, open or closed?
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: markdown
    attributes:
      value: |
        **Note:** If the submit button is disabled and you have filled
        out all required fields, check that you did not forget a Title.
```

**Notable:** This is the gold standard for CLI feature requests. Key patterns:
- **Version field** with `render: shell` for command output
- **Use Cases** explicitly asks for the end goal, NOT the solution ("focused on the problem")
- **Attempted Solutions** asks what they already tried (surfaces workarounds and existing gaps)
- **Proposal** is optional (separates problem from solution)
- **References** for linking related issues
- **Routing guidance** at the top redirects provider-specific requests elsewhere
- **Helpful hint** at the bottom about the submit button

---

### 6. Astral uv (`astral-sh/uv`) -- YAML Forms

**File:** `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/2_feature_request.yaml`

```yaml
name: Feature request
description: Suggest a new feature or improvement
labels: ["enhancement"]
body:
  - type: markdown
    attributes:
      value: |
        **Please review our guide on interacting with the issue tracker
        before opening a new issue.**

  - type: textarea
    attributes:
      label: Summary
      description: |
        A clear and concise description of what new feature or behavior
        you would like to see. If applicable, describe the current
        behavior as well.
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    attributes:
      label: Example
      description: >
        Provide an example of how the user experience would change
        or how the new feature would be used.
    validations:
      required: false
```

**Notable:** Lean and effective. The "Example" field asking for user experience changes is particularly good for CLI tools -- it implicitly asks "what would the command look like?". The file numbering (`2_feature_request.yaml`) controls template ordering in the issue picker.

---

### 7. Charmbracelet bubbletea & lipgloss -- Markdown (identical)

**File:** `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.md`

```markdown
---
name: Feature request
about: Suggest an idea for this project
title: ''
labels: enhancement
assignees: ''
---

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
A clear and concise description of what the problem is.
Ex. I'm always frustrated when [...]

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A clear and concise description of what you want to happen.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions
or features you've considered.

**Additional context**
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.
```

**Notable:** This is the default GitHub template nearly verbatim. Both bubbletea and lipgloss use identical templates. They use blank issues enabled with Discord as a contact link. Their bug report template (`bug.yml`) is actually YAML forms with a required "did you search first?" checkbox, but the feature request is still markdown -- suggesting they may not have updated it yet.

---

### 8. VS Code (`microsoft/vscode`) -- Markdown

**File:** `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.md`

```markdown
---
name: Feature request
about: Suggest an idea for this project
title: ''
labels: ''
assignees: ''
---

<!-- Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
```

**Notable:** Extremely minimal -- just HTML comments as guidelines. No labels auto-applied. VS Code relies heavily on their bot ecosystem for triage, labeling, and routing. The hidden comment `feature_request_template` is used by their bots to identify which template was used. This approach works because they have dedicated teams doing manual triage and automated tooling.

---

### 9. Rust (`rust-lang/rust`) -- External Redirect

**File:** `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/config.yml`

```yaml
blank_issues_enabled: true
contact_links:
  - name: Feature Request
    url: https://internals.rust-lang.org/
    about: Please discuss language feature requests on the internals forum.
```

**Notable:** Rust does NOT have an in-repo feature request template at all. They redirect all feature requests to the internals forum. This is a deliberate choice for very large projects where feature discussions need to go through an RFC process. Only bugs, diagnostics, documentation issues, and ICE reports are filed as GitHub issues.

---

### 10. urfave/cli (bonus -- Go CLI framework) -- Markdown

**File:** `.REDACTED.md`

```markdown
---
name: v3 feature request
about: Suggest an improvement to go into v3
title: 'your feature title goes here'
labels: 'type/feature, area/v3, status/triage'
assignees: ''
---

## Checklist

* [ ] Are you running the latest v3 release?
* [ ] Did you check the manual for your release?
* [ ] Did you perform a search about this feature?

## What problem does this solve?

A clear and concise description of what problem this feature would
solve. For example:
- needing to type out the full flag name takes a long time
- I use (osx, windows, linux) and would like support extended
- the terminal output for a particular error case is confusing

## Solution description

A detailed description of what you want to happen.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or
features you've considered.
```

**Notable:** Versioned templates (`v3-feature-request.md`) for projects maintaining multiple major versions. Pre-submission checklist. The "What problem does this solve?" section includes CLI-specific examples (flag completion, cross-platform support, terminal output). Multiple auto-labels including `status/triage`.

---

## Analysis

### Format: YAML Forms vs Markdown

| Project | Format | Why |
|---------|--------|-----|
| GitHub CLI | Markdown | Simple template, low volume |
| Go | YAML | Structured data (dropdowns, checkboxes) |
| Kubernetes | YAML | Structured, but redirects to KEP for serious features |
| Docker CLI | YAML | Structured but minimal |
| Terraform | YAML | Comprehensive structured form |
| uv | YAML | Lean structured form |
| Charmbracelet | Markdown | Default GitHub template, unchanged |
| VS Code | Markdown | Relies on bot ecosystem for structure |
| Rust | External | Redirects to forum entirely |
| urfave/cli | Markdown | Includes pre-submission checklist |

**Trend:** Newer or actively maintained projects strongly prefer YAML forms. The YAML form format provides field-level validation (`required: true`), structured input types (dropdowns, checkboxes, short input vs textarea), and a cleaner user experience. Markdown templates are either legacy or used by projects with minimal template needs.

### Common Fields Across Projects

| Field | Projects Using It | Required? |
|-------|-------------------|-----------|
| Problem / Use Case description | 8/10 | Almost always yes |
| Proposed solution | 7/10 | Usually optional |
| Alternatives considered | 4/10 | Usually optional |
| Version information | 2/10 (Terraform, urfave) | When present, yes |
| Additional context | 5/10 | Always optional |
| Pre-submission checklist | 2/10 (urfave, Go lang change) | When present, yes |
| References / Related issues | 2/10 (Terraform, Go) | Optional |
| Example / Usage example | 1/10 (uv) | Optional |
| Attempted solutions / workarounds | 1/10 (Terraform) | Required |
| Routing / scope guidance | 3/10 (Terraform, Kubernetes, Rust) | N/A (informational) |

### Best Practices for Feature Request Templates

**1. Separate Problem from Solution (Terraform pattern -- strongest recommendation)**

Terraform's approach of making "Use Cases" required and "Proposal" optional is the most effective pattern. It forces users to articulate the actual problem before jumping to their preferred solution. This is critical because:
- Maintainers can often find better solutions than what users propose
- Multiple users may report the same underlying problem with different proposed solutions
- It prevents "XY Problem" issues

**2. Ask for Concrete Examples (uv pattern)**

The uv template's "Example" field is particularly valuable for CLI tools. Asking "how would the user experience change?" naturally elicits:
- What the command invocation would look like
- What the expected output would be
- What the workflow improvement would be

**3. Include Version Information for CLI Tools (Terraform pattern)**

For CLI projects, asking for the current version with `render: shell` and a placeholder like `...output of \`entire version\`...` is highly practical. It:
- Reveals if the feature already exists in a newer version
- Helps maintainers understand the user's environment
- Uses YAML's `render: shell` attribute for proper formatting

**4. Use Structured YAML Forms Over Markdown**

YAML forms provide concrete advantages:
- **Required field enforcement** prevents incomplete submissions
- **Dropdowns** prevent free-text answers where structured data is better
- **Checkboxes** work well for "did you search first?" gates
- **Markdown blocks** allow inline guidance and routing information
- **Render hints** (`render: shell`) format code blocks automatically
- **Placeholders** guide users without cluttering the template

**5. Label Strategy**

Projects use different labeling approaches:
- **Simple:** `enhancement` (GitHub CLI, Charmbracelet, uv)
- **Workflow:** `enhancement` + `new` (Terraform) or `status/0-triage` (Docker)
- **Typed:** `kind/feature` (Kubernetes, Docker)
- **Multi-dimensional:** `type/feature, area/v3, status/triage` (urfave/cli)

For a CLI tool with manageable issue volume, `enhancement` + a triage label is a good balance.

**6. Routing Guidance for Multi-Component Projects (Terraform pattern)**

If the CLI interacts with a server, API, or plugins, include a markdown block at the top explaining where different types of requests should go. Terraform does this exceptionally well.

**7. Pre-Submission Checklist (urfave pattern)**

For projects that get duplicate feature requests, a checklist asking "Did you search first?" reduces noise. The bubbletea bug template makes this a required checkbox, which is even stronger enforcement.

### CLI-Specific Patterns Worth Adopting

**A. Command/Subcommand Context**

None of the templates above explicitly ask "which command does this relate to?" For a CLI tool with subcommands (Cobra-based), adding a dropdown of commands or asking which command area the feature relates to would help routing.

**B. Platform/Terminal Information**

The bubbletea bug template asks about terminal environment. For feature requests involving TUI elements (using Charm `huh`), knowing the terminal is sometimes relevant.

**C. Workflow Description**

The uv "Example" pattern is the most CLI-native. For a CLI tool, the ideal feature request describes the command the user wants to run and the output they expect to see. This is more useful than abstract descriptions.

### Interesting Unique Patterns

1. **Go's Experience Level Dropdown** -- Helps maintainers calibrate their response. A "Novice" requesting a feature might actually need documentation, while an "Experienced" user has likely exhausted alternatives.

2. **Go's Backward Compatibility Checkboxes** -- For CLIs that have a stability contract, understanding whether a feature would break existing behavior is critical.

3. **Terraform's "Attempted Solutions"** -- This required field is brilliant. It surfaces workarounds that might already exist (and could be documented better), and shows the user has done homework before requesting.

4. **Docker's `status/0-triage` Label** -- Embeds workflow state directly in the template. New issues automatically enter the triage pipeline.

5. **VS Code's Hidden Template Identifier** -- The `<!-- feature_request_template -->` comment enables bot automation to detect which template was used, even in markdown templates.

6. **uv's File Numbering** (`2_feature_request.yaml`) -- Controls the display order in GitHub's template picker without relying on alphabetical naming.

7. **Kubernetes' Active Redirection** -- The enhancement template's description explicitly tells users that feature requests are "unlikely to make progress as issues" and redirects them to the KEP process. This is honest and saves everyone time.

8. **Terraform's Submit Button Hint** -- The footer markdown reminds users to add a title, addressing a common UX problem with GitHub's issue form where the submit button is disabled without clear indication of why.

### Recommendation for Your CLI

Based on this research, for a Go/Cobra/Charm-based CLI tool, the strongest template would combine:

- **Terraform's structure** (problem-first, solution-optional, version info)
- **uv's example field** (show the desired command/output)
- **urfave's pre-submission checklist** (search before filing)
- **YAML form format** (field validation, structured input)
- **Docker's triage label** (workflow automation)

Here is what that would look like as a concrete starting point:

```yaml
name: Feature Request
description: Suggest a new feature or improvement
labels: ["enhancement", "needs-triage"]
body:
  - type: markdown
    attributes:
      value: |
        Thank you for suggesting a feature! Please search
        [existing issues](https://github.com/org/repo/issues?q=is%3Aissue+label%3Aenhancement)
        before filing to avoid duplicates.

  - type: checkboxes
    id: search
    attributes:
      label: Pre-submission checklist
      options:
        - label: >
            I searched existing issues and did not find
            a duplicate of this request.
          required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: problem
    attributes:
      label: Problem or Use Case
      description: |
        What problem are you trying to solve? Describe the end goal,
        not the solution. Focus on what you need, not how to get there.
      placeholder: |
        Example: When working on a large monorepo, I need to ...
        but currently there is no way to ...
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: example
    attributes:
      label: Desired Behavior / Example
      description: |
        Show what the ideal experience would look like. Include
        example commands, flags, or output if applicable.
      placeholder: |
        $ entire <command> --new-flag
        Expected output...
      render: shell
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: attempted
    attributes:
      label: What have you tried?
      description: |
        Have you tried any workarounds? Describe what you attempted
        and why it fell short.
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: proposal
    attributes:
      label: Proposed Solution
      description: |
        If you have ideas on implementation, describe them here.
        This is optional -- we are equally interested in the problem.
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: context
    attributes:
      label: Additional Context
      description: |
        Any other context, references, or screenshots.
        Link related issues with #issue-number.
    validations:
      required: false
```

This gives you the best of all the templates studied: problem-first thinking (Terraform), concrete examples (uv), duplicate prevention (urfave/bubbletea), structured validation (YAML forms), and workflow labels (Docker).

```yaml
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: tf-use-case
    attributes:
      label: Use Cases
      description: |
        Describe the end goal you are trying to achieve.
        Keep this section focused on the problem, not the solution.
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: tf-attempted-solution
    attributes:
      label: Attempted Solutions
      description: |
        If you've tried to solve the problem within existing features,
        describe what you tried. Include config snippets and command lines.
        Remove any sensitive information.
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: tf-proposal
    attributes:
      label: Proposal
      description: |
        Describe how you'd address the problem via a change to features.
        Include specific examples of config files or command line usage.
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: tf-references
    attributes:
      label: References
      description: |
        Related GitHub issues, open or closed?
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: markdown
    attributes:
      value: |
        **Note:** If the submit button is disabled and you have filled
        out all required fields, check that you did not forget a Title.
```

**Notable:** This is the gold standard for CLI feature requests. Key patterns:
- **Version field** with `render: shell` for command output
- **Use Cases** explicitly asks for the end goal, NOT the solution ("focused on the problem")
- **Attempted Solutions** asks what they already tried (surfaces workarounds and existing gaps)
- **Proposal** is optional (separates problem from solution)
- **References** for linking related issues
- **Routing guidance** at the top redirects provider-specific requests elsewhere
- **Helpful hint** at the bottom about the submit button

---

### 6. Astral uv (`astral-sh/uv`) -- YAML Forms

**File:** `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/2_feature_request.yaml`

```yaml
name: Feature request
description: Suggest a new feature or improvement
labels: ["enhancement"]
body:
  - type: markdown
    attributes:
      value: |
        **Please review our guide on interacting with the issue tracker
        before opening a new issue.**

  - type: textarea
    attributes:
      label: Summary
      description: |
        A clear and concise description of what new feature or behavior
        you would like to see. If applicable, describe the current
        behavior as well.
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    attributes:
      label: Example
      description: >
        Provide an example of how the user experience would change
        or how the new feature would be used.
    validations:
      required: false
```

**Notable:** Lean and effective. The "Example" field asking for user experience changes is particularly good for CLI tools -- it implicitly asks "what would the command look like?". The file numbering (`2_feature_request.yaml`) controls template ordering in the issue picker.

---

### 7. Charmbracelet bubbletea & lipgloss -- Markdown (identical)

**File:** `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.md`

```markdown
---
name: Feature request
about: Suggest an idea for this project
title: ''
labels: enhancement
assignees: ''
---

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
A clear and concise description of what the problem is.
Ex. I'm always frustrated when [...]

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A clear and concise description of what you want to happen.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions
or features you've considered.

**Additional context**
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.
```

**Notable:** This is the default GitHub template nearly verbatim. Both bubbletea and lipgloss use identical templates. They use blank issues enabled with Discord as a contact link. Their bug report template (`bug.yml`) is actually YAML forms with a required "did you search first?" checkbox, but the feature request is still markdown -- suggesting they may not have updated it yet.

---

### 8. VS Code (`microsoft/vscode`) -- Markdown

**File:** `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.md`

```markdown
---
name: Feature request
about: Suggest an idea for this project
title: ''
labels: ''
assignees: ''
---

<!-- Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
```

**Notable:** Extremely minimal -- just HTML comments as guidelines. No labels auto-applied. VS Code relies heavily on their bot ecosystem for triage, labeling, and routing. The hidden comment `feature_request_template` is used by their bots to identify which template was used. This approach works because they have dedicated teams doing manual triage and automated tooling.

---

### 9. Rust (`rust-lang/rust`) -- External Redirect

**File:** `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/config.yml`

```yaml
blank_issues_enabled: true
contact_links:
  - name: Feature Request
    url: https://internals.rust-lang.org/
    about: Please discuss language feature requests on the internals forum.
```

**Notable:** Rust does NOT have an in-repo feature request template at all. They redirect all feature requests to the internals forum. This is a deliberate choice for very large projects where feature discussions need to go through an RFC process. Only bugs, diagnostics, documentation issues, and ICE reports are filed as GitHub issues.

---

### 10. urfave/cli (bonus -- Go CLI framework) -- Markdown

**File:** `.REDACTED.md`

```markdown
---
name: v3 feature request
about: Suggest an improvement to go into v3
title: 'your feature title goes here'
labels: 'type/feature, area/v3, status/triage'
assignees: ''
---

## Checklist

* [ ] Are you running the latest v3 release?
* [ ] Did you check the manual for your release?
* [ ] Did you perform a search about this feature?

## What problem does this solve?

A clear and concise description of what problem this feature would
solve. For example:
- needing to type out the full flag name takes a long time
- I use (osx, windows, linux) and would like support extended
- the terminal output for a particular error case is confusing

## Solution description

A detailed description of what you want to happen.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or
features you've considered.
```

**Notable:** Versioned templates (`v3-feature-request.md`) for projects maintaining multiple major versions. Pre-submission checklist. The "What problem does this solve?" section includes CLI-specific examples (flag completion, cross-platform support, terminal output). Multiple auto-labels including `status/triage`.

---

## Analysis

### Format: YAML Forms vs Markdown

| Project | Format | Why |
|---------|--------|-----|
| GitHub CLI | Markdown | Simple template, low volume |
| Go | YAML | Structured data (dropdowns, checkboxes) |
| Kubernetes | YAML | Structured, but redirects to KEP for serious features |
| Docker CLI | YAML | Structured but minimal |
| Terraform | YAML | Comprehensive structured form |
| uv | YAML | Lean structured form |
| Charmbracelet | Markdown | Default GitHub template, unchanged |
| VS Code | Markdown | Relies on bot ecosystem for structure |
| Rust | External | Redirects to forum entirely |
| urfave/cli | Markdown | Includes pre-submission checklist |

**Trend:** Newer or actively maintained projects strongly prefer YAML forms. The YAML form format provides field-level validation (`required: true`), structured input types (dropdowns, checkboxes, short input vs textarea), and a cleaner user experience. Markdown templates are either legacy or used by projects with minimal template needs.

### Common Fields Across Projects

| Field | Projects Using It | Required? |
|-------|-------------------|-----------|
| Problem / Use Case description | 8/10 | Almost always yes |
| Proposed solution | 7/10 | Usually optional |
| Alternatives considered | 4/10 | Usually optional |
| Version information | 2/10 (Terraform, urfave) | When present, yes |
| Additional context | 5/10 | Always optional |
| Pre-submission checklist | 2/10 (urfave, Go lang change) | When present, yes |
| References / Related issues | 2/10 (Terraform, Go) | Optional |
| Example / Usage example | 1/10 (uv) | Optional |
| Attempted solutions / workarounds | 1/10 (Terraform) | Required |
| Routing / scope guidance | 3/10 (Terraform, Kubernetes, Rust) | N/A (informational) |

### Best Practices for Feature Request Templates

**1. Separate Problem from Solution (Terraform pattern -- strongest recommendation)**

Terraform's approach of making "Use Cases" required and "Proposal" optional is the most effective pattern. It forces users to articulate the actual problem before jumping to their preferred solution. This is critical because:
- Maintainers can often find better solutions than what users propose
- Multiple users may report the same underlying problem with different proposed solutions
- It prevents "XY Problem" issues

**2. Ask for Concrete Examples (uv pattern)**

The uv template's "Example" field is particularly valuable for CLI tools. Asking "how would the user experience change?" naturally elicits:
- What the command invocation would look like
- What the expected output would be
- What the workflow improvement would be

**3. Include Version Information for CLI Tools (Terraform pattern)**

For CLI projects, asking for the current version with `render: shell` and a placeholder like `...output of \`entire version\`...` is highly practical. It:
- Reveals if the feature already exists in a newer version
- Helps maintainers understand the user's environment
- Uses YAML's `render: shell` attribute for proper formatting

**4. Use Structured YAML Forms Over Markdown**

YAML forms provide concrete advantages:
- **Required field enforcement** prevents incomplete submissions
- **Dropdowns** prevent free-text answers where structured data is better
- **Checkboxes** work well for "did you search first?" gates
- **Markdown blocks** allow inline guidance and routing information
- **Render hints** (`render: shell`) format code blocks automatically
- **Placeholders** guide users without cluttering the template

**5. Label Strategy**

Projects use different labeling approaches:
- **Simple:** `enhancement` (GitHub CLI, Charmbracelet, uv)
- **Workflow:** `enhancement` + `new` (Terraform) or `status/0-triage` (Docker)
- **Typed:** `kind/feature` (Kubernetes, Docker)
- **Multi-dimensional:** `type/feature, area/v3, status/triage` (urfave/cli)

For a CLI tool with manageable issue volume, `enhancement` + a triage label is a good balance.

**6. Routing Guidance for Multi-Component Projects (Terraform pattern)**

If the CLI interacts with a server, API, or plugins, include a markdown block at the top explaining where different types of requests should go. Terraform does this exceptionally well.

**7. Pre-Submission Checklist (urfave pattern)**

For projects that get duplicate feature requests, a checklist asking "Did you search first?" reduces noise. The bubbletea bug template makes this a required checkbox, which is even stronger enforcement.

### CLI-Specific Patterns Worth Adopting

**A. Command/Subcommand Context**

None of the templates above explicitly ask "which command does this relate to?" For a CLI tool with subcommands (Cobra-based), adding a dropdown of commands or asking which command area the feature relates to would help routing.

**B. Platform/Terminal Information**

The bubbletea bug template asks about terminal environment. For feature requests involving TUI elements (using Charm `huh`), knowing the terminal is sometimes relevant.

**C. Workflow Description**

The uv "Example" pattern is the most CLI-native. For a CLI tool, the ideal feature request describes the command the user wants to run and the output they expect to see. This is more useful than abstract descriptions.

### Interesting Unique Patterns

1. **Go's Experience Level Dropdown** -- Helps maintainers calibrate their response. A "Novice" requesting a feature might actually need documentation, while an "Experienced" user has likely exhausted alternatives.

2. **Go's Backward Compatibility Checkboxes** -- For CLIs that have a stability contract, understanding whether a feature would break existing behavior is critical.

3. **Terraform's "Attempted Solutions"** -- This required field is brilliant. It surfaces workarounds that might already exist (and could be documented better), and shows the user has done homework before requesting.

4. **Docker's `status/0-triage` Label** -- Embeds workflow state directly in the template. New issues automatically enter the triage pipeline.

5. **VS Code's Hidden Template Identifier** -- The `<!-- feature_request_template -->` comment enables bot automation to detect which template was used, even in markdown templates.

6. **uv's File Numbering** (`2_feature_request.yaml`) -- Controls the display order in GitHub's template picker without relying on alphabetical naming.

7. **Kubernetes' Active Redirection** -- The enhancement template's description explicitly tells users that feature requests are "unlikely to make progress as issues" and redirects them to the KEP process. This is honest and saves everyone time.

8. **Terraform's Submit Button Hint** -- The footer markdown reminds users to add a title, addressing a common UX problem with GitHub's issue form where the submit button is disabled without clear indication of why.

### Recommendation for Your CLI

Based on this research, for a Go/Cobra/Charm-based CLI tool, the strongest template would combine:

- **Terraform's structure** (problem-first, solution-optional, version info)
- **uv's example field** (show the desired command/output)
- **urfave's pre-submission checklist** (search before filing)
- **YAML form format** (field validation, structured input)
- **Docker's triage label** (workflow automation)

Here is what that would look like as a concrete starting point:

```yaml
name: Feature Request
description: Suggest a new feature or improvement
labels: ["enhancement", "needs-triage"]
body:
  - type: markdown
    attributes:
      value: |
        Thank you for suggesting a feature! Please search
        [existing issues](https://github.com/org/repo/issues?q=is%3Aissue+label%3Aenhancement)
        before filing to avoid duplicates.

  - type: checkboxes
    id: search
    attributes:
      label: Pre-submission checklist
      options:
        - label: >
            I searched existing issues and did not find
            a duplicate of this request.
          required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: problem
    attributes:
      label: Problem or Use Case
      description: |
        What problem are you trying to solve? Describe the end goal,
        not the solution. Focus on what you need, not how to get there.
      placeholder: |
        Example: When working on a large monorepo, I need to ...
        but currently there is no way to ...
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: example
    attributes:
      label: Desired Behavior / Example
      description: |
        Show what the ideal experience would look like. Include
        example commands, flags, or output if applicable.
      placeholder: |
        $ entire <command> --new-flag
        Expected output...
      render: shell
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: attempted
    attributes:
      label: What have you tried?
      description: |
        Have you tried any workarounds? Describe what you attempted
        and why it fell short.
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: proposal
    attributes:
      label: Proposed Solution
      description: |
        If you have ideas on implementation, describe them here.
        This is optional -- we are equally interested in the problem.
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: context
    attributes:
      label: Additional Context
      description: |
        Any other context, references, or screenshots.
        Link related issues with #issue-number.
    validations:
      required: false
```

This gives you the best of all the templates studied: problem-first thinking (Terraform), concrete examples (uv), duplicate prevention (urfave/bubbletea), structured validation (YAML forms), and workflow labels (Docker).
Good research. Let me create both templates now.

name: Bug Report
description: Report an error or unexpected behavior in the Entire CLI
labels: ["bug"]
body:
  - type: markdown
    attributes:
      value: |
        Thanks for reporting a bug! Please fill out the form below.

        Before submitting:
        - Search [existing issues](https://github.com/entireio/cli/issues) to avoid duplicates
        - Try upgrading to the latest version (`entire version` to check)

  - type: textarea
    id: description
    attributes:
      label: What happened?
      description: |
        A clear description of the bug. Include the full error message or
        unexpected output. Please paste text rather than screenshots.
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: repro
    attributes:
      label: Steps to reproduce
      description: Minimal steps to reproduce the behavior. Include exact commands.
      placeholder: |
        1. `entire enable`
        2. Make some changes, then `entire checkpoint list`
        3. See error: "..."
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: expected
    attributes:
      label: Expected behavior
      description: What did you expect to happen instead?
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: input
    id: version
    attributes:
      label: Entire CLI version
      description: "Run `entire version` and paste the output."
      placeholder: "e.g., entire v0.1.0 (abc1234)"
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: input
    id: platform
    attributes:
      label: OS and architecture
      description: "Your operating system and architecture (see `uname -orsm`)."
      placeholder: "e.g., macOS 15.2 arm64, Ubuntu 24.04 x86_64, Windows 11 x86_64"
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: dropdown
    id: agent
    attributes:
      label: Agent
      description: Which AI coding agent were you using?
      options:
        - Claude Code
        - Cursor
        - Windsurf
        - Other (specify in additional context)
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: dropdown
    id: strategy
    attributes:
      label: Strategy
      description: "Which strategy is configured? (check `.entire/settings.json` or `entire status`)"
      options:
        - manual-commit (default)
        - auto-commit
        - Not sure
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: logs
    attributes:
      label: Logs / debug output
      description: |
        Relevant log output from `.entire/logs/`. If logs are long, use a
        [GitHub Gist](https://gist.github.com/). Review output for sensitive
        information before posting.
      render: bash
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: additional
    attributes:
      label: Additional context
      description: |
        Anything else that might help: Git version, shell (bash/zsh/fish),
        terminal emulator, whether running in a git worktree, tmux/SSH, etc.
    validations:
      required: false

content.text:
Bug report template is created. Now here's my proposal for the feature request template, based on the research:

## Research Summary

Across the 10 projects studied, patterns varied widely:

| Style | Projects | Fields |
|-------|----------|--------|
| **Minimal** (1-2 fields) | Docker CLI, Kubernetes | Just a description |
| **Problem-first** (3-5 fields) | Terraform, uv, GitHub CLI | Problem ‚Üí solution ‚Üí context |
| **Checklist-gated** | urfave/cli, Go (lang changes) | Search checkbox before fields |
| **External redirect** | Rust, Kubernetes (serious features) | No template, use RFC/forum |

The strongest pattern came from **Terraform** ‚Äî separating "what's the problem?" (required) from "what's the solution?" (optional). This avoids XY-problem issues and lets maintainers find better solutions. **uv** added a nice touch: asking for a concrete usage example showing the desired command/output.

## Proposed Feature Request Template

```yaml
name: Feature Request
description: Suggest a new feature or improvement
labels: ["enhancement"]
body:
  - type: markdown
    attributes:
      value: |
        Thanks for suggesting a feature! Please search
        [existing issues](https://github.com/entireio/cli/issues?q=label%3Aenhancement)
        before filing to avoid duplicates.

  - type: textarea
    id: problem
    attributes:
      label: Problem or use case
      description: |
        What problem are you trying to solve? Focus on the end goal,
        not the solution.
      placeholder: |
        Example: When working with multiple sessions, I need to ...
        but currently there is no way to ...
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: example
    attributes:
      label: Desired behavior
      description: |
        Show what the ideal experience would look like. Include example
        commands, flags, or output if applicable.
      placeholder: |
        $ entire <command> --new-flag
        Expected output...
      render: shell
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: proposal
    attributes:
      label: Proposed solution
      description: |
        If you have ideas on implementation, describe them here.
        This is optional ‚Äî we're equally interested in the problem.
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: alternatives
    attributes:
      label: Alternatives or workarounds
      description: Any workarounds you've tried or alternative approaches you've considered?
    validations:
      required: false
```

**Design decisions:**
- **4 fields, only 1 required** ‚Äî low friction, encourages submissions (Docker/Kubernetes pattern)
- **Problem-first** ‚Äî required field focuses on the "why" not the "what" (Terraform pattern)
- **Desired behavior with `render: shell`** ‚Äî natural for a CLI, shows the command they wish existed (uv pattern)
- **Proposal is optional** ‚Äî separates problem from solution, avoids XY-problem issues
- **No version field** ‚Äî unlike bugs, feature requests rarely need it (only Terraform asks, and it's a stretch)
- **No duplicate-search checkbox** ‚Äî the markdown header covers this without adding friction

Want me to create this, or would you like to adjust anything?

```
.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bug_report.yml        # 8 fields, 5 required (description, repro, expected, version, OS, agent, strategy)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ feature_request.yml   # 4 fields, 1 required (problem/use case)
```

message.content: what other templates does these repos you looked at so far have?

content.thinking: The user wants to know what other issue template types (beyond bug reports and feature requests) the researched projects have. Let me think about what I know from the research and also do a quick search to be thorough.

content.text:
From the research, here's what each project has beyond bug reports and feature requests:

| Project | Additional Templates |
|---------|---------------------|
| **GitHub CLI** | `feedback.md` ‚Äî general feedback ("What have you loved? What was confusing?") |
| **Go** | `11-language-change.yml` ‚Äî language change proposals (very structured with dropdowns, checkboxes for backward compat) |
| **Kubernetes** | Redirects to KEP process for enhancements; `config.yml` links to discuss.kubernetes.io for support |
| **Terraform** | That's it ‚Äî just bug + feature + config |
| **uv** | That's it ‚Äî just bug + feature |
| **Docker CLI** | That's it ‚Äî just bug + feature |
| **Charm** | That's it ‚Äî just bug + feature + Discord link in config |
| **VS Code** | `bug_report.md`, `feature_request.md`, plus heavy bot-based triage |
| **Rust** | `bug_report.yml`, `diagnostics.yml` (compiler error improvements), `ice.yml` (internal compiler errors), `library-tracking-issue.yml`, `regression.yml` ‚Äî all bugs redirect to forum for features |
| **urfave/cli** | Versioned templates: `v2-bug.md`, `v2-feature.md`, `v3-bug.md`, `v3-feature.md` |

The most common **third template** across projects that have one is either:

- **Documentation** ‚Äî report missing/incorrect docs
- **Regression** ‚Äî "this used to work" (separate from general bugs, with fields for "which version worked last")
- **Feedback / Questions** ‚Äî redirected to Discussions or a forum

For the Entire CLI, the most useful addition would probably be none right now ‚Äî bug + feature + config covers the basics well. If anything, a **regression** template could be interesting down the line since strategy/checkpoint behavior across versions is important, but I'd wait until there's actual volume to justify it. Keep it lean.

Want me to add any of these?

message.content: can we add a free field for the terminal used to the form?

content.text:
Which template ‚Äî bug report, feature request, or both?

My instinct is **bug report only**, since terminal matters for debugging TUI/huh rendering issues but is rarely relevant for feature requests. What do you think?

name: Bug Report
description: Report an error or unexpected behavior in the Entire CLI
labels: ["bug"]
body:
  - type: markdown
    attributes:
      value: |
        Thanks for reporting a bug! Please fill out the form below.

        Before submitting:
        - Search [existing issues](https://github.com/entireio/cli/issues) to avoid duplicates
        - Try upgrading to the latest version (`entire version` to check)

  - type: textarea
    id: description
    attributes:
      label: What happened?
      description: |
        A clear description of the bug. Include the full error message or
        unexpected output. Please paste text rather than screenshots.
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: repro
    attributes:
      label: Steps to reproduce
      description: Minimal steps to reproduce the behavior. Include exact commands.
      placeholder: |
        1. `entire enable`
        2. Make some changes, then `entire checkpoint list`
        3. See error: "..."
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: expected
    attributes:
      label: Expected behavior
      description: What did you expect to happen instead?
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: input
    id: version
    attributes:
      label: Entire CLI version
      description: "Run `entire version` and paste the output."
      placeholder: "e.g., entire v0.1.0 (abc1234)"
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: input
    id: platform
    attributes:
      label: OS and architecture
      description: "Your operating system and architecture (see `uname -orsm`)."
      placeholder: "e.g., macOS 15.2 arm64, Ubuntu 24.04 x86_64, Windows 11 x86_64"
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: dropdown
    id: agent
    attributes:
      label: Agent
      description: Which AI coding agent were you using?
      options:
        - Claude Code
        - Cursor
        - Windsurf
        - Other (specify in additional context)
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: dropdown
    id: strategy
    attributes:
      label: Strategy
      description: "Which strategy is configured? (check `.entire/settings.json` or `entire status`)"
      options:
        - manual-commit (default)
        - auto-commit
        - Not sure
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: logs
    attributes:
      label: Logs / debug output
      description: |
        Relevant log output from `.entire/logs/`. If logs are long, use a
        [GitHub Gist](https://gist.github.com/). Review output for sensitive
        information before posting.
      render: bash
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: additional
    attributes:
      label: Additional context
      description: |
        Anything else that might help: Git version, shell (bash/zsh/fish),
        terminal emulator, whether running in a git worktree, tmux/SSH, etc.
    validations:
      required: false

input.new_string:
- type: input
    id: terminal
    attributes:
      label: Terminal
      description: Which terminal emulator are you using?
      placeholder: "e.g., iTerm2, Terminal.app, Ghostty, Alacritty, Windows Terminal, Warp"
    validations:
      required: false

  - type: textarea
    id: logs

message.content: how can I test these forms while still in a branch on GitHub?

content.thinking: The user wants to know how to preview/test GitHub issue templates while on a branch (before merging to main).

content.text:
Push the branch and navigate to the issue template URL with a `template` query param:

```
https://github.com/entireio/cli/issues/new?template=bug_report.yml
```

```
https://github.com/entireio/cli/issues/new?template=feature_request.yml
```

The catch: **GitHub only loads issue templates from the default branch** (usually `main`). Templates on a feature branch won't render through the normal UI.

### Workarounds

1. **Temporarily change the default branch** ‚Äî In repo Settings > General > Default branch, switch it to your feature branch, test the forms, then switch back. Quickest way to test.

2. **Push to a fork** ‚Äî Fork the repo, push the branch as `main` on the fork, and test there. No risk to the real repo.

3. **YAML validation only** ‚Äî If you just want to check for syntax errors without visual preview, GitHub will show YAML parse errors when you push. You can also validate locally:
   ```bash
   python3 -c "import yaml; yaml.safe_load(open('.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/bug_report.yml'))"
   ```

Option 2 (fork) is the safest for a shared repo.
